headline.main: WASHINGTON.; The President's Return--An Incident on the Way--His Health--Site for an Assay Office in New-York.

docs.lead_paragraph: The President and Cabinet, and the several gentlemen traveling with him, arrived here safely at 10 o'clock last evening, having come the entire distance from New-York in special trains provided by the liberality of the several roads. No accident occurred--no draw-bridges were open-no switches misplaced. The air was delightfully cool,

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

headline.main: French Ships and French Emigration to California.

docs.lead_paragraph: From the San Francisco Herald. We consider it only an act of impartiality to render justice to the French vessels which have brought to California such a large number of French emigrants. These have all been well treated during the voyages, and have arrived here in perfect health, with little or no mortality.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Sunday, July 17, 1853, of consumption, in full confidence of a blessed immateriality, FREDERICK VICKERY GREENLEAF, aged 24 years, 1 month and 25 days. Funeral on Tuesday (this) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from the residence of his mother, No. 4 Astor-place. The relatives and friends of the family are affectionately invited to attend. The remains will be interred in Union Cemetery, Bushwick.

headline.main: BROOKLYN CITY.; MORTALITY. THE RAILROAD SUBJECT. INDIAN VISITORS. TAXES. BRUTAL ASSAULT. FATAL ACCIDENT. SERIOUS ACCIDENT.

docs.lead_paragraph: MORTALITY.--The Health Officer reports 88 deaths in this city for the week ending July 17, males 47; females, 41; adults, 33; children, 65. Diseases.--Cholera infantum, 14; marasmus, 13: Consumption, 8; diarrhoea and still born, 5 each; dropsy in the head and dysentary, 4 each : cholera, congestion of the brain, convulsions, croup, inflamation of the lungs, 3 each; cancer of the womb, drowned,

headline.main: FRANCE.; Religions Lotteries--The Opera--Paints Royal--American Papers--Postal Difficulties--General News, & c.

docs.lead_paragraph: The directors of the lottery for the restoration of the Church of Notre Dame de Perthes, announce that the time for the drawing is nigh; that a good many lucky numbers are believed to be still unsold; and that people desirous of contributing to a worthy object would do well to apply at once, as only a few tickets are left.

byline.original: Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Saturday was a day which must have delighted the heart of Mr. THOMAS HOPE. It was a day of frequent, sudden, unexpected and heavy showers ;--one of those days which tempt men and women out of doors without umbrellas, and then drench them with a flood of rain. The Sixth and Eighth-avenue cars ran full all day; and as men,

headline.main: THE WAR OF 1812.; Biographical Sketch of Capt. John Price.

docs.lead_paragraph: Capt. JOHN PRICE, whose death occurred a few weeks since, at Burlington, Vt., was one of the best soldiers of the war of 1812. He was in four general actions, and in every service of danger that presented itself, and always earned the applause of his comrades, and the high approbation of his officers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The New-York Medical Gazette for July has several interesting papers. Dr. A. TROWBRIDGE reports several cases of lithotomy, to extract foreign bodies from the bladder. Dr. C. H. CLEVELAND commends galvanism for uterine hemorrhage--a use of a very dubious remedy, which must be far more thoroughly tested than it has hitherto been, before the profession generally will accept it, we opine. Prof. PAUL. F. EVE,

docs.lead_paragraph: The City Post-Office ought to stand upon the lower angle of the Park. That is by all odds the most central and accessible point in the City. All the great routes of City travel,-all the modes of conveyance through the City,-centre there.
docs.abstract: Post Office in the South end of the Park - (Ed)
